The scale of the survey (nearly 2,000 respondents across 105 countries) makes it a high-credibility benchmark.

sources.body_html:
The State of AI in the Enterprise: 2026 AI Report

Summary

Deloitte's 2026 State of AI in the Enterprise report tracks the shift from AI ambition to activation across global organizations. The report identifies that organizations stand at the "untapped edge" of AI's potential, with worker access to AI rising by 50% in 2025. The number of companies with 40% or more of their AI projects in production is set to double in six months, signaling a transition from piloting to scaling.

The report finds that twice as many leaders as last year report transformative AI impact, but only 34% are truly reimagining their business through AI. Productivity and efficiency top the list of achieved benefits (66% of organizations), followed by enhanced insights and decision-making (53%), cost reduction (40%), and enhanced client/customer relationships (38%). Revenue growth remains largely aspirational, with 74% hoping to grow revenue through AI compared to just 20% currently achieving it. The report also highlights critical gaps: the AI skills gap is seen as the biggest barrier to integration, with education — not role or workflow redesign — being the primary talent strategy adjustment. Agentic AI usage is poised to rise sharply, but oversight is lagging, with only one in five companies having a mature governance model for autonomous AI agents.

Key Takeaways

  • Worker access to AI rose by 50% in 2025; companies with 40%+ projects in production set to double in six months
  • Twice as many leaders report transformative AI impact compared to last year, but only 34% are truly reimagining their business
  • 66% of organizations report productivity and efficiency gains from enterprise AI adoption
  • 53% report enhanced insights and decision-making; 40% report cost reduction
  • Revenue growth largely aspirational: 74% hope for it, only 20% achieving it
  • AI skills gap is the biggest barrier to integration; education is the No. 1 talent adjustment strategy
  • Only 1 in 5 companies has a mature governance model for autonomous AI agents
  • 42% of companies believe their strategy is highly prepared for AI adoption, but feel less prepared on infrastructure, data, risk, and talent
  • Physical AI gaining traction: 58% report at least limited use today, expected to reach 80% in two years

Notable Quotes

"Organizations today stand at the untapped edge of AI's potential. Success hinges on the ability to move boldly from ambition to activation." — Deloitte 2026 AI Report

"Improving productivity and efficiency top the list of benefits achieved from enterprise AI adoption so far, with two-thirds of organizations reporting gains." — Deloitte 2026 AI Report

Relevance to Topic

This report provides a comprehensive view of enterprise AI maturity that directly applies to project management. The finding that skills gaps — rather than technology — represent the biggest barrier mirrors challenges in PM AI adoption. The governance gap for agentic AI (only 1 in 5 companies with mature models) is particularly relevant as PM tools increasingly incorporate autonomous agents. The contrast between strategic readiness (42%) and operational preparedness across infrastructure, data, risk, and talent illuminates the gap that PMOs must bridge.

sources.title: KPMG AI Quarterly Pulse Survey: AI at Scale — How 2025 Set the Stage for Agent-Driven Enterprise Reinvention in 2026
sources.author: KPMG
sources.body_html:
KPMG AI Quarterly Pulse Survey: AI at Scale

Summary

KPMG's Q4 2025 AI Quarterly Pulse Survey, released January 2026, reveals that enterprise AI has shifted decisively from experimentation to production-grade scaling. Based on eight consecutive quarters of proprietary research, the report finds that organizations are "professionalizing" their AI agent systems rather than simply deploying more agents. Average AI investment climbed from $114M in Q1 to $130M in Q3 2025, with 67% of leaders indicating they will maintain AI spending even in a recession. Agent deployment surged from 11% in Q1 to 26% by Q4 2025.

The survey surfaces a critical finding for project management: 44% of leaders expect AI agents to take lead roles in managing specific projects alongside human teams over the next 2-3 years. This represents a fundamental shift in how project delivery may be structured. System complexity has replaced other concerns as the No. 1 deployment challenge, with 65% of leaders citing agentic system complexity as the top barrier. Cybersecurity is the single greatest barrier to achieving AI strategy goals (80% of leaders), with data privacy (77%) and data quality (65%) rising sharply as concerns.

Key Takeaways

  • 44% of leaders expect AI agents to take lead roles in managing specific projects alongside human teams in 2-3 years
  • AI investment averaged $124M per enterprise, projected over the coming year; 67% will maintain spending even in recession
  • Agent deployment surged from 11% (Q1 2025) to 26% (Q4 2025), more than doubling
  • 59% of enterprises expect measurable ROI within 12 months
  • 65% of leaders cite agentic system complexity as the top deployment barrier for two consecutive quarters
  • 80% of leaders say cybersecurity is the single greatest barrier to achieving AI strategy goals (up from 68% in Q1)
  • 64% of organizations have already altered entry-level hiring approaches due to AI agents' influence (up from 18% previous quarter)
  • 76% of leaders willing to offer up to 10% higher compensation for candidates with strong AI skills
  • 40% of leaders say board members now have substantial AI expertise (five-fold increase from 8% two quarters prior)
  • New roles emerging: AI prompt engineer, AI performance analyst, AI trainer/data curator

Notable Quotes

"AI isn't just an investment, it's becoming the backbone of enterprise strategy. What the numbers don't show is the growing divide: while some organizations stall after early deployments, the leaders are scaling fast and pulling ahead." — Steve Chase, Vice Chair of AI and Digital Innovation, KPMG LLP

"2026 will be the year we begin to see orchestrated super-agent ecosystems, governed end-to-end by robust control systems that drive measurable outcomes and continuous improvement." — Swami Chandrasekaran, Global Head of KPMG AI and Data Labs

"The topline adoption number undersells what's actually happening among leaders. They're not pulling back, they're professionalizing their agents and agent systems." — Steve Chase, KPMG

Relevance to Topic

This is one of the most directly relevant sources for AI in project management. The finding that 44% of leaders expect AI agents to co-lead projects is a signal of fundamental change in PM practice. The shift from "deploying agents" to "professionalizing agent systems" mirrors the PMO maturation journey. The emphasis on system complexity as the top barrier, rather than technical capability, suggests that orchestration and governance — traditional PMO competencies — become more important as AI scales. The quarterly longitudinal data provides trend visibility that point-in-time surveys cannot.

sources.title: AI in Project Management: 2025 Software Trends Report
sources.author: Capterra (Gartner subsidiary)
sources.body_html:
AI in Project Management: 2025 Software Trends Report

Summary

Capterra's 2025 Project Management Software Trends Survey, conducted in July 2025 among 2,545 respondents across 11 countries (Australia, Brazil, Canada, France, Germany, India, Italy, Mexico, Spain, UK, and US), provides one of the most comprehensive quantitative assessments of AI adoption in PM software purchasing. The survey's central finding is that AI has become the primary driver of PM software investment: 55% of buyers reported that AI was the top trigger for their most recent PM software purchase.

The report maps current AI usage across PM functions: 54% of project managers use AI for risk management, 53% for task automation, 52% for predictive analysis and forecasting, 52% for schedule optimization, and 47% for resource planning and allocation. However, adoption faces significant barriers: 41% of project managers said AI adoption is a challenge, 39% reported a lack of AI skills on staff, and 36% said integrating new tools into existing workflows is a significant hurdle. The report also identifies that AI is raising the stakes for security, with organizations grappling with new security risks alongside the productivity opportunities. A regional variant found that 57% of Canadian project managers cited AI as the trigger for a PM software purchase in the previous year, even amid budgetary constraints.

Key Takeaways

  • 55% of PM software buyers reported AI was the top trigger for their most recent purchase
  • Survey covered 2,545 respondents across 11 countries (July 2025)
  • 54% use AI for project risk management, 53% for task automation, 52% for predictive analysis, 52% for schedule optimization, 47% for resource planning
  • 41% of PMs say AI adoption is a challenge
  • 39% report a lack of AI skills on staff
  • 36% say integrating new tools into existing workflows is a significant hurdle
  • AI is raising the stakes for security — organizations face new risks alongside AI opportunities
  • 57% of Canadian PMs cited AI as the trigger for PM software purchase (regional finding)
  • Companies investing in AI-powered tools to tackle rising project complexity, tighter budgets, and shifting workforce dynamics
  • Generative AI used for drafting documents, summarizing meetings, answering questions; ML for schedule optimization; predictive analytics for risk identification

Notable Quotes

"This isn't about chasing shiny features. It's about tackling rising project complexity, resource constraints and the demand for speed." — Olivia Montgomery, Associate Principal Analyst, Capterra

Relevance to Topic

This is the most directly relevant practitioner survey on AI in PM tool adoption. The 2,545-respondent sample across 11 countries provides robust quantitative evidence. The finding that AI is now the top purchase trigger (55%) signals a market inflection point. The barrier analysis (skills gaps, integration challenges, security risks) provides actionable data for organizations planning AI-enabled PM tool adoption. As a Gartner subsidiary, Capterra's methodology and sample quality lend credibility to the findings.

sources.title: Accenture Technology Vision 2025: AI-Powered Autonomy and Enterprise Reinvention
sources.author: Accenture

Accenture Technology Vision 2025: AI-Powered Autonomy and Enterprise Reinvention

Summary

The 25th annual Accenture Technology Vision, informed by surveys of more than 4,000 executives across 21 industries and 28 countries, plus over 12,000 consumers, explores how AI-powered autonomy is reshaping enterprise operations. The central thesis: a new era of digitization is unfolding in which AI continuously learns and drives new levels of autonomy across organizations, positioning trust in its performance as the most important measure for AI to achieve its promise.

The report identifies trust as the critical enabler: 77% of executives believe the true benefits of AI will only be possible when built on a foundation of trust, and 81% agree that trust strategy must evolve in parallel with technology strategy. The vision spans four dimensions: technology development (gen AI coding assistants elevating developers to systems engineers, shifting from static application architecture to intention-based frameworks and agentic systems), customer experience (80% of executives worry LLMs could give every brand a similar voice), the physical world (generalist robots emerging over the next decade), and workforce transformation (80% of leaders prioritize ensuring a positive relationship trajectory between people and AI). The report notes that AI diffusion is accelerating faster than any prior technology, with 69% of executives believing this brings new urgency to reinvention.

Key Takeaways

  • 69% of executives believe AI brings new urgency to reinvention of technology systems and processes
  • 77% of executives believe the true benefits of AI will only be possible when built on a foundation of trust
  • 81% agree that trust strategy must evolve in parallel with technology strategy
  • 80% of executives worry LLMs and chatbots could give every brand a similar voice
  • 80% of leaders prioritize ensuring a positive relationship trajectory between people and AI
  • Gen AI coding assistants are elevating the role of developer to systems engineer
  • Shift from static application architecture to intention-based frameworks and agentic systems
  • Multi-agent systems becoming more capable, adaptive, and personalized
  • Accenture platforms (GenWizard, SynOps, AI Refinery) offer prebuilt industry agents and workflows
  • Trust means digital systems and AI models are more accurate, predictable, consistent, and traceable — beyond responsible use of AI
  • Survey covered 4,000+ executives across 21 industries and 28 countries, plus 12,000+ consumers

Notable Quotes

"Unlocking the benefits of AI will only be possible if leaders seize the opportunity to inject and develop trust in its performance and outcomes in a systematic manner." — Julie Sweet, Chair and CEO, Accenture

"The autonomy created by these generalized AI systems can help organizations be more dynamic and intention-driven than ever. It will allow leaders to rethink how digital systems are designed, how people work, and reinvent how they create products and interact with customers. But trust underpins it all, as systems will only ever be as autonomous as they are trustworthy." — Karthik Narain, Group Chief Executive, Technology and CTO, Accenture

Relevance to Topic

While not PM-specific, this report provides critical context on the trust dimension of AI adoption that directly applies to project management. The finding that systems are "only ever as autonomous as they are trustworthy" is particularly relevant for agentic PM tools that make autonomous scheduling, resource allocation, or risk assessment decisions. The shift from static architectures to intention-based and agentic systems maps onto the evolution of PM tools from passive tracking to autonomous project assistance. The scale of the research (4,000+ executives, 12,000+ consumers) across 21 industries provides a robust foundation for cross-industry insights.

sources.title: Boosting Business Acumen: PMI Pulse of the Profession 2025
sources.author: Project Management Institute (PMI)
sources.body_html:
Boosting Business Acumen: PMI Pulse of the Profession 2025

Summary

The 2025 PMI Pulse of the Profession report, based on a survey of nearly 3,000 project professionals worldwide, focuses on business acumen as a key factor in driving project success. While AI is not the primary focus, the report provides essential context for understanding how AI fits into the broader competency landscape of project management. Only 18% of project professionals demonstrate high business acumen proficiency, yet these individuals achieve significantly better outcomes: 27% lower failure rates and 5 percentage points better goal achievement.

The report finds that only approximately 20% of project managers report having extensive or good practical AI skills, highlighting a significant capability gap in the profession. High business acumen professionals use an average of 9.1 factors to measure project performance versus 6.3 for other professionals, and 83% consider customer satisfaction a performance metric (versus 66%). The report positions business acumen and technological competency as complementary capabilities, suggesting that project professionals who master both become "indispensable strategic partners." Despite senior leaders acknowledging the need for new business acumen skills (54%), investment priorities still favor technical skills (64%) and power skills (61%) over business acumen development.

Key Takeaways

  • Survey of nearly 3,000 project professionals worldwide
  • Only 18% of project professionals demonstrate high business acumen proficiency
  • High business acumen PMs achieve 27% lower project failure rates and 5pp better goal achievement
  • Only ~20% of PMs report having extensive or good practical AI skills
  • 83% of projects led by high business acumen PMs meet business goals (vs. 78% for others)
  • Projects led by high business acumen PMs have an 8% failure rate (vs. 11% for others)
  • High business acumen PMs use 9.1 performance measurement factors on average (vs. 6.3 for others)
  • 54% of senior leaders acknowledge teams need new business acumen skills
  • 64% prioritize technical skill development; 61% prioritize power skills; business acumen trails both
  • When facing scope challenges, 93% prioritize stakeholder management; when facing budget issues, 91% prioritize stakeholder management
  • Business acumen and AI skills positioned as complementary capabilities for "indispensable strategic partners"
  • GenAI applications already span the project lifecycle: automated meeting summaries, stakeholder updates

Notable Quotes

"Only 18% of project professionals demonstrate high business acumen proficiency, yet these individuals achieve remarkable results: 27% lower failure rates and 5 percentage points better goal achievement." — PMI Pulse of the Profession 2025

Relevance to Topic

This report provides an essential counterpoint to the technology-focused AI narrative: business acumen — not AI proficiency — is PMI's identified differentiator for high-performing project professionals. The low AI skills rate (~20% with practical competence) alongside the low business acumen rate (18% with high proficiency) suggests that the profession faces a dual capability gap. For AI adoption in PM, this implies that technical AI capability alone is insufficient; project professionals need business judgment to determine where and how AI adds value. The stakeholder management emphasis (93% prioritize it for scope challenges) also underscores the human competencies that AI cannot replace.

sources.title: Announcing The Forrester Wave: Collaborative Work Management Tools, Q2 2025
sources.author: Margo Visitacion and Melissa Chhay (Forrester)
sources.body_html:
Announcing The Forrester Wave: Collaborative Work Management Tools, Q2 2025

Summary

Forrester's Q2 2025 Wave evaluation of Collaborative Work Management (CWM) tools assessed 11 vendors — Adobe, Airtable, Asana, Atlassian, ClickUp, monday.com, Quickbase, ServiceNow, Smartsheet, Wrike, and Zoho — across 15 current-offering criteria and 8 strategy criteria. Each vendor was evaluated through a questionnaire, executive strategy briefings and demos, and interviews with up to three reference customers. The evaluation reflects a market in rapid evolution, where AI-driven capabilities are becoming central to competitive differentiation.

The report's key insight for project management practitioners is that CWM tools have evolved beyond project or task planning to empower users to act, drive outcomes, and perform work proactively. Three critical considerations emerge: integration depth is crucial (beyond surface-level, assessing flexibility and scalability), AI depends on data quality (clean, well-structured, accessible data is essential for reliable AI outputs), and project portfolio management remains essential — CWM solutions are not yet full replacements for traditional PPM systems. The portfolio management gap is particularly notable: governance, scalability, and robust data models required for enterprise-scale planning are still maturing in many CWM platforms.

Key Takeaways

  • Forrester evaluated 11 CWM vendors: Adobe, Airtable, Asana, Atlassian, ClickUp, monday.com, Quickbase, ServiceNow, Smartsheet, Wrike, Zoho
  • Evaluation covered 15 current-offering criteria and 8 strategy criteria
  • CWM tools have evolved from project/task planning to outcome-driven work platforms
  • AI capabilities are no longer optional — they are central to competitive differentiation in PM tools
  • AI value depends on data quality: clean, well-structured, accessible data is a prerequisite for reliable AI-driven recommendations
  • CWM platforms are not yet full replacements for traditional Project Portfolio Management (PPM) systems
  • Portfolio management at enterprise scale requires governance, scalability, and robust data models still maturing in CWM
  • Integration depth with the broader tech ecosystem is essential — surface-level integrations are insufficient
  • Organizations are starting to implement CWM tools as a system of record for work
  • The CWM market continues fast-paced growth with expanded capabilities

Notable Quotes

"AI can be a powerful accelerator for productivity, but its value is only as strong as the data it relies on — clean, well-structured, and accessible data is essential for generating reliable outputs and building trust in AI-driven recommendations." — Forrester Wave, Q2 2025

"CWM solutions are flexible and allow for proactive work, but they are not yet full replacements for traditional PPM systems." — Forrester Wave, Q2 2025

Relevance to Topic

This Forrester evaluation provides an authoritative assessment of the AI capabilities embedded in mainstream PM tools that enterprise practitioners actually use. The finding that CWM tools are not yet PPM replacements is particularly important — it suggests organizations need a layered approach where AI-enhanced CWM handles execution while separate PPM capabilities handle governance and portfolio-level decisions. The data quality prerequisite for AI effectiveness reinforces findings from other sources in this collection.

sources.title: AI Will Transform Project Management. Are You Ready?
sources.author: Marc Lahmann (PwC Switzerland)
sources.body_html:
AI Will Transform Project Management. Are You Ready?

Summary

This PwC Switzerland article by Marc Lahmann, Partner in Strategy & Transformation, outlines a four-phase evolutionary model for AI in project management: (1) Integration & Automation, (2) Chatbot Assistants, (3) Machine Learning-Based PM, and (4) Autonomous Project Management. While published in 2018, the evolutionary framework it describes has proven prescient — the industry in 2025-2026 is transitioning from phases 1-2 (automation and chatbot assistants) into early phase 3 (ML-based PM), with phase 4 (autonomous PM) still largely theoretical.

The article distinguishes between automation (controlled processes following pre-programmed rules) and AI (designed to simulate intelligent thinking) — a distinction that remains relevant as many "AI" features in PM tools are actually rule-based automation. For each evolutionary phase, the article provides specific real-world use cases: Phase 1 includes MS Project Online integration with task tools and automated budget/scheduling alerts; Phase 2 includes Fireflies.ai for conversation processing and Stratejos.ai for performance tracking; Phase 3 would involve predictive analytics and autonomous schedule adjustment; Phase 4 would involve self-driven project management with minimal human intervention.

Key Takeaways

  • Four-phase AI evolution model for PM: Integration & Automation, Chatbot Assistants, ML-Based PM, Autonomous PM
  • Crucial distinction between automation (rule-based) and AI (intelligent simulation) — many "AI" PM features are actually automation
  • Phase 1 (Integration & Automation): streamlining standardized tasks, auto-scheduling, exception-based alerts; reduces costs and frees PMs for complex work
  • Phase 2 (Chatbot Assistants): bots handling meeting organization, progress checks, reminders; initial data insights from conversational interfaces
  • Phase 3 (ML-Based PM): predictive analytics, autonomous schedule adjustments based on pattern recognition; requires substantial historical data
  • Phase 4 (Autonomous PM): self-driven project management; still theoretical and faces significant obstacles
  • AI application to PM dates back to 1987 (William N. Hosley, PMI Project Management Journal), though practical adoption is recent
  • Automation will reduce costs and free PMs to focus on stakeholder management and complex activities
  • Real-world examples cited: Fireflies.ai (conversation processing in Slack), Stratejos.ai (team performance tracking)
  • Key obstacle: data quality and availability — AI needs historical project data to learn from

Notable Quotes

"There is something AI cannot do — be human." — PwC Switzerland

"Automation is a controlled process that follows pre-programmed logic and rules, while AI is designed to simulate intelligent and even human thinking." — PwC Switzerland

Relevance to Topic

Though published in 2018, this article's evolutionary framework for AI in PM remains the most widely cited maturity model in the field. Comparing the 2018 predictions against 2025-2026 reality provides a useful calibration: phases 1 and 2 have materialized broadly, phase 3 is emerging, and phase 4 remains distant. The article's emphasis on the distinction between automation and genuine AI is a useful analytical lens for evaluating current PM tool claims.

sources.title: Accountable Acceleration: Gen AI Fast-Tracks Into the Enterprise (2025 AI Adoption Report)
sources.author: Wharton Human-AI Research and GBK Collective
sources.body_html:
Accountable Acceleration: Gen AI Fast-Tracks Into the Enterprise

Summary

The third annual Wharton/GBK Collective study tracks generative AI's trajectory from exploration (2023) through experimentation (2024) to "accountable acceleration" (2025). Surveying approximately 800 U.S. executives, the study documents a clear maturation pattern: weekly GenAI usage rose from 37% (2023) to 72% (2024) to 82% (2025), with daily usage now at 46%. The 2025 report's central theme is the pivot from speculative adoption to rigorous, disciplined pursuit of value — what the authors term "accountable acceleration."

The study finds that 72% of leaders now formally measure GenAI ROI, focusing on productivity gains and incremental profit. Three out of four leaders report positive returns on their initial AI investments. Looking ahead, 88% anticipate GenAI budget increases in the next 12 months, with 62% expecting increases above 10%. About one-third of GenAI technology budgets are being allocated to internal R&D, indicating enterprises are building custom capabilities. The study also identifies a tension: 89% agree GenAI enhances employees' skills, yet 43% see risk of declines in skill proficiency — echoing concerns about AI-driven deskilling. Chief AI Officer roles are now present in 61% of enterprises.

Key Takeaways

  • Weekly GenAI usage: 37% (2023) to 72% (2024) to 82% (2025); daily usage now at 46%
  • Three-wave evolution: Exploration (2023) to Experimentation (2024) to Accountable Acceleration (2025)
  • 72% of leaders formally measure GenAI ROI, focusing on productivity gains and incremental profit
  • 75% of leaders report positive returns on GenAI investments
  • 88% anticipate GenAI budget increases in next 12 months; 62% expect increases above 10%
  • About one-third of GenAI budgets allocated to internal R&D — building custom capabilities
  • 89% agree GenAI enhances employees' skills, but 43% see risk of skill proficiency decline
  • Chief AI Officer roles present in 61% of enterprises (up significantly)
  • IT and Purchasing/Procurement lead on adoption frequency and confidence; Marketing/Sales and Operations lag
  • Most effective use cases: data analysis, document summarization, and document editing/writing
  • Training, hiring, and rollout approaches are key human capital aspects for success
  • Four out of five leaders see GenAI investments paying off in about two to three years

Notable Quotes

"The next phase is not about adoption; it is about advantage. The companies that thrive will be those that pair measurable ROI with responsible integration and build a culture where people have the skills to grow with AI." — Jeremy Korst, Partner, GBK Collective

"The challenge isn't replacement, it's readiness. Companies that invest in training, culture, and guardrails will be the ones that turn Everyday AI into long-term advantage." — Stefano Puntoni, Wharton School

"Leaders are no longer content to run pilots. They want proof. Gen AI is being held to the same standards as other major investments, and that is a sign of increasing maturity." — Sonny Tambe, Wharton School

Relevance to Topic

This longitudinal study provides the strongest evidence for the shift from experimentation to accountability in enterprise AI. While not PM-specific, the findings directly apply: the demand for measurable ROI from AI investments will increasingly reach PM tools and practices. The tension between skill enhancement (89%) and skill degradation risk (43%) is highly relevant to the project management profession's concerns about AI replacing PMs. The identification of data analysis and document summarization as top use cases aligns with the PM tasks most amenable to AI automation.

sources.title: AI in Project Management: Benefits, Use Cases & Future Outlook
sources.author: Anna Balyuk (Epicflow)
sources.body_html:
AI in Project Management: Benefits, Use Cases & Future Outlook

Summary

This comprehensive article from Epicflow, an AI-powered project resource management software provider, surveys the current and future applications of AI in project management, grounding its analysis in data from Gartner, PMI, KPMG, and HBR sources. While vendor-authored, the article provides substantive analysis through extensive references to third-party research and expert quotes, particularly from Paul Boudreau, an AI researcher and author of "The Self-Driven Project."

The article addresses a key question: the Gartner prediction that 80% of PM tasks will be run by AI by 2030 does not mean replacement, but rather automation of non-core tasks (email, scheduling, status reports) while project managers lead the strategic and collaborative work. Boudreau provides three reasons AI will not replace PMs: data must be organized by a PM before ML algorithms work, AI provides insights that require human interpretation and action, and outcomes depend on collaboration between AI and experienced PMs. The article cites PMI research showing companies using AI-driven tools achieve 61% on-time delivery (vs. 47% without), 69% business benefits realization (vs. 53%), and 64% meeting ROI estimates (vs. 52%). KPMG research indicates companies investing in AI report 15% average productivity improvements for their projects.

Key Takeaways

  • Gartner predicts 80% of PM tasks run by AI by 2030 — but this means automation of non-core tasks, not PM replacement
  • Three reasons AI will not replace PMs (Paul Boudreau): data needs human preparation, insights need human interpretation, outcomes need human-AI collaboration
  • Companies using AI-driven PM tools: 61% on-time delivery vs. 47% without AI (PMI research)
  • AI-using companies: 69% realize 95%+ of business benefits vs. 53% without AI (PMI research)
  • AI-using companies: 64% meet or exceed ROI estimates vs. 52% without AI (PMI research)
  • Companies investing in AI report 15% average productivity improvements for projects (KPMG)
  • Six areas AI will disrupt PM (per HBR): selection/prioritization, PMO support, project definition/planning/reporting, virtual assistants, testing systems, PM role redefinition
  • AI most valuable in multi-project environments with shared resource pools: enormous data volumes, numerous inter-project dependencies, many variables, high uncertainty
  • AI-powered scenario planning (What-if analysis) enables testing environment changes and analyzing future consequences
  • Small companies running a few projects may not benefit from AI; value increases with portfolio complexity

Notable Quotes

"Being able to talk to your email instead of typing or having meetings scheduled automatically are not really project management tasks. Project managers need to embrace AI and lead the change to the way projects are managed." — Paul Boudreau, AI researcher and author

"Project specific tasks include actively managing activities on the critical path, determining the impact of change requests on all areas of the project and minimizing the impact of risk events on the project scope, schedule and budget. These are the areas where AI tools offer the greatest benefit." — Paul Boudreau

Relevance to Topic

Despite being vendor-authored, this source adds value through its compilation of third-party research data (PMI, KPMG, Gartner) quantifying AI's impact on PM outcomes. The on-time delivery improvement (61% vs. 47%) and benefits realization data (69% vs. 53%) from PMI provide some of the strongest quantitative evidence for AI's value in PM. The article's framing around multi-project portfolio environments as the primary beneficiary of AI is a useful analytical lens that other sources do not emphasize.

sources.title: Adapting to the Era of GenAI: Evolution of Project Management Practices
sources.author: Nicole Hackl and Andrea Torres (PwC Austria)
sources.body_html:
Adapting to the Era of GenAI: Evolution of Project Management Practices

Summary

This PwC Austria article by Nicole Hackl (Senior Manager) and Andrea Torres (Senior Associate) in Portfolio & Programme Management examines how GenAI is impacting project management and PMO operations. The article frames the opportunity around a stark statistic: organizations invest approximately $48 trillion in projects annually, but only 35% are considered successful (Forbes, 2023). It argues that GenAI could be the "game changer" for improving these outcomes by combining AI with project management automations.

The article covers five areas: embracing GenAI in PM (AI-driven insights and task automation enabling project managers to navigate complexity with agility), revolutionizing PMO operations (the era of project scoping and repetitive reporting fading away, with GenAI projected to handle 80% of PM tasks by 2030), unique challenges (data quality, security, AI bias, and the need for "human in the loop"), redefining PM roles (project managers as "outcome stewards" ensuring fairness in AI applications), and empowering virtual project assistants (AI-driven companions for task organization and progress updates). The article emphasizes that GenAI empowers project managers to focus on creativity and human-approach tasks such as coaching teams, managing stakeholder relationships, and improving leadership skills.

Key Takeaways

  • Organizations invest approximately $48 trillion in projects annually; only 35% are considered successful
  • 75% of companies planning to integrate AI by 2027 (World Economic Forum)
  • By 2030, GenAI projected to handle 80% of PM tasks (Gartner, 2019 prediction)
  • GenAI is not eliminating PM but empowering PMs to focus on creativity, coaching, stakeholder management, and leadership
  • Project managers will assume the role of "outcome stewards" ensuring fairness in AI applications
  • AI models carry biases from human-created training data — PMs need to manage this
  • "Human in the loop" strategy is crucial: human judgment must supplement AI decision-making
  • Key challenges: data quality and availability, security concerns, integrating AI into existing processes
  • AI does not possess "true understanding" of content — accumulated knowledge based on training data
  • Soft skills investment is critical now as AI handles more administrative and analytical tasks
  • Organizations need a clear GenAI strategy addressing risk/reward balance, digital strategy alignment, and people-centricity

Notable Quotes

"GenAI is not here to eliminate project management but rather to empower project managers to focus on initiatives that require creativity and a human-approach, such as coaching their teams, managing stakeholder relationships and maybe even improving their leadership skills." — PwC Austria

"By 2030, GenAI will be capable of handling 80% of project management tasks, powered by big data, machine learning, and natural language processing." — PwC Austria citing Gartner

"Project managers will assume the role of 'outcome stewards', ensuring fairness in AI applications." — PwC Austria

Relevance to Topic

This article provides a European consulting firm perspective on GenAI in PM, introducing the concept of the project manager as "outcome steward" — a role focused on ensuring AI-driven fairness and quality rather than task execution. The $48 trillion annual project investment figure, combined with the 35% success rate, quantifies the opportunity for AI to improve project outcomes. The emphasis on soft skills as the critical competency for AI-era PMs supports the broader finding across sources that AI augments rather than replaces project management expertise.

The State of Project Management Annual Report 2025

Summary

Wellingtone's annual State of Project Management Report, published since 2016, captures insights from hundreds of industry professionals on the current landscape of project management in the UK and globally. The 2025 edition covers PM maturity, essential tools and techniques, project success rates, and PMO effectiveness. Data is collected through an extensive questionnaire, rigorously analyzed, anonymized, and also shared with leading universities for academic research.

The report reveals persistent challenges in project delivery alongside growing PMO adoption. Only 31% of projects are reported as successful (on time, on budget, on scope), while 82% of organizations now operate one or more PMOs. A critical finding: 42% of respondents spend one or more days each month manually collating project reports — representing a clear automation opportunity for AI. Resource management, benefits management, and project prioritization are identified as the three most difficult PM processes to embed. On the AI front, the report finds that organizations plan to increase AI investments by 36%, and by 2026 an estimated 80% of PMOs are expected to use AI for decision-making. However, significant barriers remain: resistance to change from team members (26%), lack of skilled personnel (19%), data integration and quality issues (17%), and high costs and budget restraints (15%).

Key Takeaways

  • Only 31% of projects are successful (on time, on budget, on scope)
  • 82% of organizations now operate one or more PMOs
  • 42% of respondents spend 1+ days per month manually collating project reports
  • 47% do not have access to real-time project KPIs
  • 72% believe the scope and responsibilities of their PMO will get larger in the future
  • Three most difficult PM processes to embed: benefits management, resource management, project prioritization
  • Organizations plan to increase AI investments by 36%
  • 80% of PMOs expected to use AI for decision-making by 2026
  • AI adoption barriers: resistance to change (26%), lack of skilled personnel (19%), data integration/quality issues (17%), cost/budget constraints (15%)
  • 53% of projects are run by non-certified project managers; only 47% by certified professionals
  • 71% of companies believe employees need more project management skills
  • 62% of organizations anticipate an increase in project work
  • 53% expect to shift toward working in smaller, more agile teams
  • 11% of organizations have no project management solutions at all

Notable Quotes

"42% of respondents spend 1 or more days manually collating project reports." — Wellingtone State of PM Report 2025

"72% believe the scope and responsibilities of their PMO will get larger in the future." — Wellingtone State of PM Report 2025

Relevance to Topic

This report provides the ground-level practitioner perspective on PM operations, revealing the specific pain points that AI could address (manual reporting, lack of real-time KPIs, resource management). The 42% manual reporting statistic directly quantifies the efficiency opportunity for AI in PM. The barrier analysis — led by resistance to change (26%) rather than technology limitations — suggests that the challenge of AI adoption in PM is primarily organizational and cultural, not technical. The certification gap (53% of projects run by non-certified PMs) also raises questions about how AI tools will be adopted by practitioners with varying levels of PM maturity.
